document.masterDocTitle: Philippistenia, a new Disteniini genus from the Philippines (Coleoptera: Disteniidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Philippistenia, a new Disteniini genus from the Philippines (Coleoptera: Disteniidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Museu de Zoologia, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Distenia heterotarsalis Heller, 1923
, here designated.

Diagnosis.
Philippistenia
gen. nov. can be differentiated from other genera of Disteniini by the following characteristics: head distinctly narrowed behind eyes; lateral tubercles of prothorax directed upward; elytra pubescent, with longitudinal bands of dense black pubescence, always present on suture; metafemora linear, unarmed apically, and long, almost reaching elytral apex; and metatarsomere I at least as long as II + III.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–5. 1-3. Detail of posterior area of head and pronotum. 1.
Distenia
( D .) columbina Lepeletier & Audinet-Serville, 1828; 2.
Philippistenia levitemporalis ( Heller, 1924 )
; 3.
Typodryas callichromoides Thomson, 1864
; 4–5. Detail of the elytra showing the longitudinal black bands of pubescence. 4.
Philippistenia samarensis ( Villiers, 1959 )
; 5.
Philippistenia heterotarsalis ( Heller, 1923 )
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. The name
Philippistenia
is a compound of the words Philippines , referring to the country where the species of the new genus are distributed, and
Distenia
. Feminine gender.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 6–19. 6–18.
Distenia
( D .) columbina Lepeletier & Audinet-Serville, 1828, male. 6. Dorsal view; 7. Ventral view; 8. Lateral view; 9. Frontal view; 10–18. Male terminalia. 10. Tergite VIII; 11. Sternite VIII; 12. Ventral arc; 13–15. Tegmen. 13. Dorsal view; 14. Ventral view; 15. Lateral view. 16–18. Median lobe. 16. Dorsal view; 17. Ventral view; 18. Lateral view; 19.
Typodryas callichromoides Thomson, 1864
. Scale = 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The genus
Philippistenia
differs from
Distenia
( Figs 1 , 6–18 ) by the head distinctly narrowed behind the eyes ( Fig. 2 ); elytra with longitudinal bands of dense black pubescence, always present on the suture ( e.g. Figs 4–5 ); and the metafemora long, almost reaching the elytral apex. In
Distenia
, the head is not strongly narrowed behind the eyes ( Fig. 1 ); the elytra do not have longitudinal bands of dense black pubescence ( Fig. 6 ); and the metafemora are short, just reaching the apical third of the elytra. Comparing the male terminalia of
Philippistenia species
with the male terminalia of
Distenia
( D .) columbina ( Figs 1–18 ) is possible to observe that in the latter the tergite VIII ( Fig. 10 ) and the apophysis of sternite VIII ( Fig. 11 ) are longer than in
Philippistenia
, and the parameres of tegmen are divergent apically ( Fig. 13–15 ) (in
Philippistenia species
are subparallel).

The new genus can be also differentiated from
Typodryas Thomson, 1864
( Fig. 19 ) by the absence of transversal wrinkles on the vertex and pronotum ( Fig. 2 ), and the elytra with longitudinal bands of dense black pubescence. In
Typodryas
, the vertex and pronotum have transversal wrinkles ( Fig. 3 ) and the elytra do not have longitudinal bands of black pubescence.

Philippistenia
can be differentiated from
Novantinoe Santos-Silva & Hovore, 2007
by the pronotum with the medial tubercle slightly elevated, poorly visible; elytra with longitudinal bands of dense black pubescence; and the metafemora long, almost reaching the elytral apex. In
Novantinoe
, the medial tubercle of pronotum is well elevated and clearly visible; the elytra do not have longitudinal bands of black pubescence, and the metafemora do not reach the elytral apex.
Novantinoe
is geographically restricted to the New World.

Currently,
Philippistenia
is an endemic genus from the Islands of the Philippines ( Fig. 71 ).
